Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a very solid simulation/tycoon game, however it does suffer from a few setbacks. There isn't much in the way of a tutorial, so it might take a few trys before you find your stride. My first prison ran more like a concentration camp, but by the third I had the game figured out. That being said, there wasn't much motivation to create a fourth. Once you've established a prison that can run essentially without any input from you, there is the option to sell the prison and begin anew with the profits. Do this once or twice, of course, and you've really done everything the game has to offer. Still, the same argument might be had for a large majority of the tycoon games out there, so it's not enough of a drawback for me to not recommend the game. Four Stars.

Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm a fan of builder-sims in general. I think giving players a large set of digital tools and then giving them the freedom to create to their hearts content stimulates higher brain function and makes for high game replayability. Prison Architect delivers a rather unique experience--I can't think of any other prison building games--that's thoroughly enjoyable regardless of whether its your first prison or your 61st. Even better, the devs continue to actively update the game with content, tweaks, etc. I highly recommend giving this game a shot.

Posted: December 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								8.5/10For a game so early in the development stages, this game will suck  you in for hours, encouraging you to build the best prison you possibly can. Starting with a quite creepy introduction on the basic mechanics of the game, it leaves you with nothing but some workers, pieces of paper telling you what to do, and a ton of steel and concrete. Get to work!The game slighty guides you on the basic needs and necessities of your prison by giving you goals with grants, accessible through the reports menu. If you manage to get the ball rolling by smoothly following the grants, you will be left to earn money for yourself by holding prisoners, which is definately a not-so-fun option compared to getting money by grants. After this stage, your development will help the prisoners become more comfortable, passive, or even helpful in some cases. This game, being very early in development, is very buggy at sometimes, and can frustrate you if you don't catch it soon enough. The devs are ironing out the game very periodically though, so I am quite sure bugs will be a thing of the past sometime soon. A great game recommendable to anyone, especially with the small price tag and amount of sales on this game. Get out there, beat your prisoners with batons, and make them do the dishes in Prison Architect!

Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								At this current time this game is in a early access state as it has been for some time now. I have played around 50 hours on this game so far and can safely say that i will be playing many, many hours on this game. It is highly addictive and is great to be able to make your own prison where you get to map it out, hire your staff, choose in sandbox whether to have low, medium or high risk prisoners. The higher the risk the more money they bring into your prison. You have to be on the ball and plan your prison out quickly as prisoners can quickly riot, smuggle weapons/tools/luxuries and attempt to escape. I had one enjoying but challanging instance where i had 100 high risk prisoners rioting at once, killing all my guards before doing a big break out. At that point i needed to sell my prison to start again. A thing about this game is that in time you will learn from a lot of mistakes but it has great potential and requires minimal graphical requirements to play this game, which i think is great! Awesome game, highly recommend it as it is very addictive. xD

Posted: November 2, 2015
												   In Prison Architect you build and manage a prison. The game is pretty basic but complete and with nice artwork. There is a short campaign that also serves as a tutorial. The game is not very challenging in itself and seems pretty hard to really mess things up. I also believe that the inmates get ahold of "contraband" too easily.   Version 1.0 comes with "Escape Mode" where you get to play a prisoner. It's a very fun experience to try to escape from a prison that you built.Rating: What are you in for?   Downloading a car... :(http://pixelloot.com

Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Summary: A wonderfully created and well thought out game. There is obvious love in this series with the sky being the limit with the type/amount of content this developer could add. I highly recommend anybody interested in creating their own prison, or even thinking about "hey I need a new building game," to give this little gem a shot.Post 8 hour summary: Prison architect is an easy to learn, but harder to master, game that involves delicate manipulation of prisoner populations in order to run a successful and profitable prison. The indie nature of the game is apparent but adds to the charm of this title with the easily animated "circles" of characters happily whistle and glide throughout the lengths of your prison in comical fashion. Donot, however, feel like this game will be a walk in the park for even experienced sim users. If you do not quickly address your prisoners needs you will soon learn that beneath the "friendly" nature of the game lies a darker system of violence, blood shed, and even death. I mean, who wants to see their favourite K9 get killed in a mass riot?(review to continue)Positive:+ Wonderfully complex prisoner mood/attitude system+ Moderate learning curve with steep learning curve to mastery+ Regular content updates to keep things fresh and bugs minimal+ Graphics are delightfully comical considering the "dark" nature of the gameNegative- Certain tools, such as cloning, could use additional work- Worker AI still manages to trap themselves in rooms- Tutorial could be expanded to cover more topics

Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing Early Access Game!Here is the summary:Start with an empty plot of land with $30000 (Or infinite money, if you turned on sandbox)Choose your first government grants and start building.Get a perimeter and holding cell, along with required standards (canteen, shower, etc.) up. Bring in prisoners.Now that you have a basic infrastructure, do WHATEVER YOU WANT with your prison. Make it a resort of happiness, a max security box of death, a balanced prison, etc. you can add a death row block too. A great modding system (thanks to steam as well) lets you add more things to do in your game, as once you have a maxed out prison it gets more boring. Mods help fix the boredom. If you want to make it even more fun, you can save your game then start a riot. YEAH! Then, reload your save if you want to still have functioning prison. Or, try to rebuild AFTER the giant riot (extra challenge!)If you go bankrupt, too many people die, or you do have an uncontrollable riot, if you enabled 'failure conditions' you can actually lose the game!Negatives -Even now, there are still some bugs leftEven with mods, once you have built everything, it gets a little bit boring. Overall - 9.5/10-ALPHA 36 NOTE-They have added in gangs! If you enable gangs, they add a huge amount of fun and challenge to the game. Once a legendary prisoner joins a gang and becomes leader, all hell breaks loose. The prisoners will start controlling areas. Your guards can still enter those areas, but you cant edit those areas (e.g. placing objects) until you evict the prisoners, which starts a huge fight! AWESOME!Also, the dev team has added in new rooms and features since my original comments! Buy the game and CHECK THEM OUT!

Early Access Review
								So, i have this game for like, umm, 2 hours and i have like one hour played? Yeah, sounds about right. Well, i was interested in this game since it's announcement, however, i didn't back it back then. And with this purchase, i realized how stupid it was not to back it / preorder it back then. 'Cause this game is absolutely stunning. For a comparison, it's more complex Sim City, but prison themed. When you start the game for the first time, you'll be welcomed with a 10 minute introduction which will show you how does the game system work. However, it doesn't show you everything, but this is compensated with the ingame wiki, but still, you will have to search for some guides on the internet. But that's just a minor problem as the game is still in the alpha stage. And that's what surprises me at most. I've never seen a game in the alpha stage that is polished like this one. Everything seems to work so far and there aren't any major bugs or glitches. The graphic style of the game is also awesome - it's little bit cartoonish and cellshaded - and i like that. The detail of every single prisoner is absolutely outstanding, too. You can view prisoner's bio, which is impressively detailed and so on. Every prisoner also has a name and traits, so the game gets really personal in this branch. Also with the new update, the riots have been added to the game, so if you won't keep your prisoners happy, there is a chance that your prison will change into a warzone. I also like the building system. Remember how in the games like Sim City, Prison Tycoon, Zoo Tycoon and many other games was the building only a matter of the single click and no waiting? Well in this one, you can forget it. First, you have to wait for the material to arrive, second, you have to wait for the workers to obtain it and unpack it and actually BUILD IT. This improvement adds that realism feeling to the game, and that's how i like it. Well, to end this review - it's hard to judge the game now, in the alpha stage, as the developers can ♥♥♥♥ it up or make it even better that it is right now, but in this state, the game is ABSOLUTELY AWESOME AND YOU SHOULD GET IT! YOU WON'T REGRET, I PROMISE!My verdict as of 2.5. 2014: 99% (-1% because of the short tutorial)

Posted: November 28, 2016
												Definitely one of my favourite games. If you are like me and love strategy games, resource management games, tycoon games, and upgrade games, then this is the game for you. The replay value in this game is insane. I have built dozens of prisons for prisoners with different levels of security and with different goals for my prison in mind but (in my opinion) the best part of Prison Architect is managing your prison. Monitoring the prisoner's needs to prevent riots, assigning prisoners like snitches and ex-cops to protective custody, sweeping for controband, adding security precautions where needed, and hiring guards and staff are all things you can do in Prison Architect. Also, for an added layer of difficulty, there is not an option to have gangs in your prison.

Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Back in the day I was a huge city builder fan. I loved the old SimCity games where you could focus more on the outline of your city and make everything ”feel” good for you. Than the later games have added plenty of tiny functions that I never really liked that much. The micro management was never really THAT fun there. Prison Architect gives me that awesome feeling that those older city builders did, focusing on building and having fun rather than micromanagement. I can build a prison that have a layout and style that I like. And once you've finished a huge chunk of the prison you can start to micromanage the different sections and rules of the prison and even though I didn't like that in the citygames I love it here! Becuase everything you change have an almost emediate effect on your prison. I also love that this is one of those games that actually keeps getting updated! You get new things and new game rules to play around and the game is even getting a bit harder (and that's a good thing). Truly my only complaint about Prison Architect is the fact that once you've gotten far enough with your build it can be a bit slow. You're prison is safe, you're guard do their job and you keep getting money to advance babysteps forward. And that means waiting for that money you need to keep building. Some time ago you could even let the game run by itself to just get money and not really losing anything for doing so. Overall a great city bu.... prison building game that will bring you hours and hours of gaming fun. Recommended. / Nurgleprobe

Posted: July 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Prison Architecht is one of those games i could play for hours and hours. In its current state i would still say its worthwile, there are many annoying bugs, a lot of which appear to have been fixed, since the "bug bash" last month. it is a very playable game and doesent have many game breaking bugs that i have seen. At the moment it lacks an endgame, however its updated monthly (most of the time) and everytime they release a new feature it keeps me going for several hours straight until ive had my fill, where i leave it for the next update.There are features at present which dont get used much it would seem, my prison has never caught fire for example. The prisoners used to tunnel every day to escape. They no longer bother at all. I put this down to how i play. This shows the quality of the game as what you do affects the game in a manner that you would expect - i treat my prisoners right, give them what they need and they dont kick up a fuss unless something changes. its difficulty is interesting. its pretty easy to get the hang of it i would say, one of those trial and error games for a few hours, but its not annoying, your learning and having fun with the game, its not a problem to start over and your prison gets better each time. its quite clever, becuase you only have to expand as much as you want to. The layout of your prison is important, but it doesent mean you cant have a great working prison if your layout is rubbish - its great to run a prison and find out why your prisoners are getting annoyed, so you can fix it. The ways you can do this are numerous. You can just have more guards in certain areas, or armed guards, to really quiet them down. but if you have a good layout, and good schedule for them you dont need to. i would say im pretty good at the game, this has actually led to the game being a bit boring as my prison runs very nicely, and requires little to no help from me. The rehabilitation side of the game, has a lot of promise in it, and is causing me to rethink my prison layout once again, in oder to rehabilitate as many of the prisoners as possible. Some may think its rather pricey, and thats understandable, and with the simple graphics and what might appear to be limited gameplay there is a chance youd be annoyed with your purchase. I followed the game for sometime before buying, so i knew more of what to expect and i wasnt dissapointed. You will probably find yourself playing for a large stint at first as its quite addictive. You will soon grasp the game and play it more efficently. Eventually you will hit the early access wall where you wait for new features to come out. this for me at least, is the trend of early access games. I have confidence the endgame portion of prison architect will round off the game very nicely, but until then, i am content with the monthly updates. If you dislike early access games for being incomplete, this is no different, its not finished, but if you like strategy/simulator games you will enjoy this for many hours before you hit the "wall" i talked about, the other thing is that this early access model allows for more playability, as you often have to change aspects of your prison each time there is a new update. i got the game around the tunnels update. after that was the dogs, and now the budget and rehab stuff. Overall, if you like sims and strategy games even in its early access form its worthwhile. To score it is tricky, as im expecting the game to be finished eventually, which leads me to the score of 7/10, in its completed state i imagine it to be an 8 or even a 9/10.

								This is a fantastic game.  I didn't use an explanation point because it's just a fact. Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Prison architect is your regular build and sruvive game with very intersting setting aka building perfect prison and keeping inmates safe and calm. Game is of course in early access so it will definetely change and evolve so keep that in mind.Tutorial - I really like the idea to make it something more like intro and letting player get immersed with whole prison setting, But for now I feel like creators had interesting idea but let it go and it feels lackluster. The tutorial part is too shallow and confusing and the story is too short. This can be much more interesting, especially with follow up in form of story driven missions/scenarios.Gameplay - considering this is work in progress I'm very satisfied in the way how the game works. So there is a nice UI with prison planning, clone tool. The AI works fine and gets job done for majority of time, be it prison personel or inmates themselves. Graphiscs are basic, quite clearly protrating everything with some artistic feeling.There is one major issue I have - you can build too nice prison without any challenge by chaining various projects that doesn't require any prisoners. I feel that game should have slower buildup with lower funds at the beginning so you have to put some compromises, instead having it all. My 2nd prison got to 100 capacity with absolutely no problems - no riots, escapes and no difficulty. Too easy too fast.I like the idea to make some inmates unique with various hidden perks and having nice background story and even graphics. Yet I think it's prisoners "psychology" that should be the major feature. As much as it's fun to have big prison full of inmates operating flawlessly I'd love to have more micromanagment of various prisoners(and guards), that react differently to cookie-cutter treatment. This will not only make game much more challenging but also each playtrough will be more unique with most favorite and hated personalities.The game is currently in great spot, easily worth the purchse already and it's really interesting to see and experience how it developes.

Posted: August 29, 2016
												Prison architect is fun. The main game mode is, as the title suggests, being a prison architect. However, you can also be a prisoner in a megaprison of the computer's design. At first, I thought the game was insanely hard. I had a bunch of criminals waiting on the sidewalk while I tried to make a dorm room with no cash at all. Over time, however, the game got easier. The money I got from the inmates flooding in meant I rarely had to worry about bankruptcy. I expanded my prison to house hundreds of inmates, including dozens of super-maximum security prisoners, and added doctors, guards, and more cooks so the prisoners stopped dying of starvation, fights, and wounds inflicted by guards. This was going swimmingly until I realized that more than 40 prisoners had escaped through a tunnel, causing me to get fired. This game has a ton of options for how you want to run your prison, such as a single concrete depressing building or a expansive grassy enjoyable paradise. You can do whatever you want with this game. 10/10.

								A rather compelling sim game which initially looks simple but the deeper you delve in the more there is to it. An easy going open ended style has you try to get grants based on how you wish to run your prison, gaining half up front while the other half comes when you complete the objectives. A bit of a steep learning curve and sometimnes your mistakes are not easily fixed. I restarted a few times once I realize dmy mistakes weren't worth correcting, once you understand the flow of the game and make sure you understand th reqs for the rooms and how some of the slightly more complex items work you will begin to construct your mega prison or clubhouse for felons, either way. Got this on sale for 5 bucks, great deal. For 30.00 I may wait for a few of the bugs to be worked out. The ONLY complaint I have was when the vehicles on the road stalled out when prisoners were in the road and after several days of trying to tget them to move I realized I will just have to start over, I am truthfully not that disappointed to start off and make one even better.

Posted: June 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Prison architect is a game that allows you to play out your wildest dreams and submit your wildest nightmares upon unsuspecting inmates. You are the designer, builder and warden of a prison where you get to control every aspect of the prisoners lives from the food that they eat, to when they get to take a sh*t to the kind of punishment they'll receive when they sass one of your guards. You have complete control and the power is in your hands to either create a peaceful rewarding prison that encourages rehabilitation, or a nightmarish hell-hole where your prisoners are restrained at all times in a tiny cell and fed through a hole in the door.

Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Prison Architect is a very cool Sandbox game. [WARNING!] IT IS JUST IN ALPHA, SO DONT GET MAD FOR BUGS IF YOU BOUGHT IT ! As i said, it is only in Alpha stage, but a LOT of progress has been done. So, you start with a road, bunch of workers, and a field, that your prison will be on. You (atleast should) start with a holding cell for your first peeps, then you build a canteen and a shower. Then you can start to build individual cells, and then a yard, and then a visitation room and i could go, and go, and go with those thing but it would be so long, that it would took so much time, and nobody likes such long reviews. Anyway, the game lets you put in your custom prisoner. YES, you can even create Gabe as i saw that someone sent his apply, and he will be in-game after the next update. You can find lots of cool prisoners. There is even Snoop Dogg, CJ from GTA:SA and lots of cool prisoners. This game could really suck your time. We shouldn't care for the bugs ATM because it's just Alpha and we know that they'll eventually fix 'em.+Really addicting+Very Cool+Not complicated (well, it is but only a little bit)+Graphics are cute+You can put in custom prisoners-Bugs (As i said, it's only Alpha, so we shouldn't care about them)-The music in the background feels like... Like it's just not there-Sometimes, if you don't pay atention, your prison could be a giant mess.Overall : 9/10[Alpha overall, if they release the full game i might change it]

Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Prison architect is your regular build and sruvive game with very intersting setting aka building perfect prison and keeping inmates safe and calm. Game is of course in early access so it will definetely change and evolve so keep that in mind.Tutorial - I really like the idea to make it something more like intro and letting player get immersed with whole prison setting, But for now I feel like creators had interesting idea but let it go and it feels lackluster. The tutorial part is too shallow and confusing and the story is too short. This can be much more interesting, especially with follow up in form of story driven missions/scenarios.Gameplay - considering this is work in progress I'm very satisfied in the way how the game works. So there is a nice UI with prison planning, clone tool. The AI works fine and gets job done for majority of time, be it prison personel or inmates themselves. Graphiscs are basic, quite clearly protrating everything with some artistic feeling.There is one major issue I have - you can build too nice prison without any challenge by chaining various projects that doesn't require any prisoners. I feel that game should have slower buildup with lower funds at the beginning so you have to put some compromises, instead having it all. My 2nd prison got to 100 capacity with absolutely no problems - no riots, escapes and no difficulty. Too easy too fast.I like the idea to make some inmates unique with various hidden perks and having nice background story and even graphics. Yet I think it's prisoners "psychology" that should be the major feature. As much as it's fun to have big prison full of inmates operating flawlessly I'd love to have more micromanagment of various prisoners(and guards), that react differently to cookie-cutter treatment. This will not only make game much more challenging but also each playtrough will be more unique with most favorite and hated personalities.The game is currently in great spot, easily worth the purchse already and it's really interesting to see and experience how it developes.

Posted: January 16, 2014
												I love this game. I've spent dozens of hours trying different variations of prisons to optimise efficiency. Personally i love the riots, fights and great escapes conducted by in-mates. There are some irritating bugs but not game breaking. One example is workers or staff getting stuck between walls or clipping edges. It's like the game doesn't know what to do with the worker/staff so they just sit there till you sack them. You can always employ more staff. I expect more features and bug fixes by the time it is released. This review is written for Prison Architect Alpha version 16.Update Alpha version 28 / 27 Dec 2014:After tracking this game for a year the developer is still contantly releasing improvements and patches to previous issues. I've logged nearly 90 hours into it and still find it extremely fun to build my prison and then watch the inmates and staff do their thing. I loved shaking down the prison and seeing what kind of contraband will be found. I found an inmate collecting 22 spoons and he wasn't even trying to escape. Watching your prison burn down is also hilarious. The community /steam workshop also bring out mods which help improve the functionality and aesthetics of the game which is a big plus. I think PA is very playable in its alpha build and you should definitely pick up this game this Christmas!Update 7 October 2015:It actually left early access! 11/10.

Posted: May 29, 2016
												So. I backed this game back during the Kickstarter and didnt' really play it all that often. It was one of those games that I was like, eh, okay. It's a cool concept, not for me... Until I had two weeks off work and I was bedbound. This game has taken over my life.  This game, from the last time I played it, has progressed and grown into such a beautiful, enjoyable simulator. Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Solid entertainment and great value for money. Very addictive. This game will steal many, many hours from you.However.. despite all the great things that can and have been said about this game, remember it is an alpha. There are bugs. Lots of them (more than 3000, according to the latest alpha release video). I haven't experienced crashes or corrupted save games or anything like that, but sooner or later you will run into bugs that are really annoying. Like the fact that garbage dropped in a jail door tile will keep the door open at all times, and because the game doesn't recognize drops in a door tile, the garbage will never be picked up by a janitor. Imagine what a permanently open jail door can do for a prison. So yeah.. stuff like that..The UI isn't great, and it's obvious that the more new features the developers add, the more cramped and unintuitive the UI gets. It really needs an overhaul to be efficient. But it's an alpha, so maybe it will get one at some point.There's little to no guidance for new players to introduce them to the game mechanics. All it offers is a useless tutorial where you build an electric chair, that isn't really used for anything in the actual game. If you want to know what the various buildings does (what purpose they have) you have to look it up on the wiki. For end game players there's a distinct lack of feeling of progress. The tech tree is pretty small, it doesn't take long to max everything out.But, having said all that: buy this game. It's great.

Posted: July 17, 2016
												As a huge sandbox genre lover Prison Architect has been on my to-play list for quite some time, and I wasn't disappointed after getting it. It's literally what it claims to be - you are an architect of a prison, with the added pleasure of getting to manage it as well. One would think that there is only so much you can do with such an idea, but in this game it has been executed really well so far.I honestly did not expect what this game actually offers from it. Apart from a few silly problems the mood and psychology of each individual prisoner in your prison are a very nice touch. Some are more troublesome than the others (and you don't usually know that right away, you have to learn it throughout the gameplay) and some may be something like ex-law enforcement and that will make them get in trouble with other prisoners a lot should they not be watched at all times. Unhappy prisoners obviously cause trouble, and that includes the need to see their family, sleep, entertainment, comfort, so on, but even greatly unsatisfied they will be hesitant to do anything if you put armed patrols around them. Or snipers. That creates a great variety of ways in which your prison can be ran - Do you want to have a luxury Swedish prison with bacon and eggs for breakfast every day or would you rather be in charge of a war prison where your prisoners don't even have beds? It's all there.Your prisoners will also make greater efforts to escape if they feel unhappy in your prison, while, if you treat them well, they almost can't be bothered to do so. They will take the opportunity if the door is open, but can also attempt things like digging tunnels, or even causing riots. It is essential you design your prison well, because a strategic placement of things like main entrance, armoury or door-control systems actually matters in case things go really bad. You can also assign patrols, put metal detectors in chokeholds, instal phone taps, all sorts of things to ensure your prison is secure and contraband-free (because your prisoners will attempt to smuggle it in A LOT).There is also a campaign mode but there is not a whole lot to it, really. There is a story going on that one could be interested in but it didn't really catch my attention that much; it's basically a tutorial where you learn how things work. I, myself, just stick to the sandbox.The game obviously has its flaws, but it's constantly getting improved and it's already more than I expected from a would-seem-simplistic sandbox game. I'd say that if I can get 50 hours into just sandboxing and placing walls around without any purpose then somebody had to do something right.

Posted: July 19, 2016
												Almost feels likes it should be in early access there's so much polishing needed to be done. Nonetheless, a satisfying game with a story that expresses the two competing models of crinimal justice, the retribution/deterence and the medical model, mostly competently. Something almost laughable if it wasn't so tragically accurate was that there was no regulation whatsoever on the placement of family cells and nurseries in female prisons. Whatever your view on criminal justic, you cannot be putting completely innocent, vulnerable children so close and at farily easy access to dangerous convicts. C'mon world.

Posted: July 19, 2016
												Want to explore the morality of the prison industrial system? If so, this game is for you! Don't want to get into the issues of for-profit-prisons? That's fine too! Design your prison to be efficent with the goal of rehabilitating criminals... or just go all out cruelty with "tough on crime" tactics! The choice is yours! Fortunately, the premise of Prison Architect is matched up with well designed strategy mechanics which challenge you to expand your prison as your budget grows. Reinvest those profits to make even more profit! Or just go all out with sandbox mode where you have unlimited funds. One thing of note, you might want to watch some basic tuitorals in order to figure out how some of the UI works. Simple things like building foundation instead of walls to make an "indoors" area might not be obvious when you first start playing. Other than that, Prison Architect is fantastic!

												Good fun startegy/simulation type game. This isn't your simple minded Theme Hospital though. There's a shed load of gameplay to be found in what is a suprsingly deep prison simulator that has everything from simply housing prisoners and taking care of their basic needs, to reforming them with an effort to subside re-offending.Play through the campaign to begin with to get small but helpful story that acts as a backdrop to help you learn the ropes. It's a tad more than your typical tutorial but is arranged in such as way to not have you feel like you are being inundated with detailed systems. After that go wild in an open sandbox starting with a small prison and ramping it up to a large one containing multiple levels of security and a crazy amount of staff who are all unique and required to assist your prisoners and prison itself function.

Prison Architect ReviewSimualtion and tycoon game based on prison.Prison Architect is a must-have in your Steam library. I absolutely love games with the "Play God" like style. It means you control everything and manage everything. It also is unbelievable how fun it is to create riots, fire and commotion inside your own prison. Especially if you've built it yourself. You hire staff, you tell them what to do, they do it. Guards, riot police, doctors, dog handlers, firemen, managers, workmen, gardeners, janitors and all that jazz. Brilliant game and a must have, yes, it's in Alpha and contains a few little bugs but the game is playable and very enjoyable. Thumbs up to developers!I love this game so much that I have infact, to support the developers, bought all of the developers games and bought the expansion for Prison Architect so I can have myself as a prisoner in the game.

Early Access Review
								I have become a huge fan, I have always been a fan of simulation games especially all out builders like this For an early release game I am amazed at the quality this is already the mechanics just FEEL right it feels balanced and feature full with plenty to do to manage your population. Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I acquired this game without really knowing too much what it was I was getting in to. What I got was an oddly thought-provoking sim/management game that leads you through a fairly brutal introduction to the prison system, then follows it up with a game that presents you options in surprisingly subtle shades of gray. Your best intentions of providing your prisoners with a fair quality of life and a prison experience must be balanced against the need to handle more and more prisoners, and a finite amount of money to pay for it. Sacrifice the quality of prison life at your peril as unhappy prisoners are more likely to re-offend, and cause disruptions to prison operation. Run out of money and you are in real trouble. The game is incredibly clever in this regard making each and every choice one that impacts the next and you can quickly snowball to failure rather than successfully walk the tightrope of keeping your prison functioning at peak efficiency.

Posted: December 8, 2013
Early Access Review
								So, this will be my third review of this game as it has developed and since we have received the announcement that it won't be in Alpha come October, I think its time for an update. I would just like to say that this game, is the only game that has kept my faith in Early Access alive. The developers have been amazing with on-schedule, monthly updates accompanied by videos that are HILARIOUS to watch. Anyway onto the game...Prison Architect, the name says it all, you build a prison. Simple no? No...Game play 8.5/10Its a sandbox game so there are really multiple ways of playing the game with several starting options to increase or decrease "difficulty". However, starting out brand new you have minimal cash and must work your way up from the ground. Worrying about everything from walls to food to Bubba getting a chance to speak to his mom, I was definitely unprepared when I opened my gates to prisoners for the first time with a small holding cell a kitchen and some showers. And that was before they added advanced contraband scripts, traits that allow prisoners to maul your guards with ease and gangs. Needless to say the game play is amazing with so many more factors to worry about other then surrounding some Sims with walls. And while Prison Architect is rather hard to "fail" if your prison gets to out of hand, say bye bye to your prison.Graphics 10/10Ok, the graphics aren't super high end amazing, but ♥♥♥♥ you I love that simple♥♥♥♥♥♥ Basic sprites with minimal animations but I find it classic, nostalgic and endearing.Sound 6/10Soundtrack is nothing special, simple sounds for certain things like building and vehicles but you aren't walking around talking to your prisoners anyway, you're watching them from above like a god.Replay value 9/10For me, this game is mainly about the replay. Your first prison is going to suck, hopefully it will make you some money however because you can sell it once you reach a certain point in the game, and have that cash to build a new one. So unless you want to just keep renovating the same prison and slowly grind away for cash, its the only way of getting a larger prison. Particularly in Alpha I found this game highly repayable due to the monthly updates with new toys, but I doubt it will drop much as a finished project.

Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
IntroductionPrison Architect is a game about creating a prison (well duh). You must build all of the offices, all of the cells, water and electricity lines, and hire staff! The game at first may not seem complicated, but when you first play it... wow do things change! You start out with a clever tutorial that puts you in the place of a prison that is already built, but you must build an execution building. There is a short storyline to the tutorial, but it does not transfer over to the normal game after. CustomizationAs of the time writing this review you are given eight different options when creating your prison.Size - You are given the options small, medium, and large for your prison size.Fog of War - You will not be able to see into your prison where you do not have guards or CCTV camerasContinuous Intake - Prisoners will arrive every 24 in-game hours You can disable this in-game later.Generate Forests - Trees will generate on your land. You must clear these before building.Generate Lakes - (Experimental) Will generate lakes on your land that will block construction.Generate Buildings - Random deserted buildings left on your land. You may use this as you wish.Failure Conditions - You will lose the game if you let things get too bad, like riots, bankruptcy, too many deaths or escapes, etc.Unlimited Funds - Sandbox mode! You can spend as much money as your heart desires, and you do not need to worrySteam Workshop is integrated. I have not personally tried it, but I have heard that it is fantastic and has a great modding community!You can build your prison however you like it! I'm not going to tell you what you can or cannot do, as that is part of the fun of the game! Look up prison architect timelapse videos to see what you are able to do in the game!GameplayEvery prisoner has their own status. Some require drugs, others just want freedom and wanting to talk to family. Some want to just play games, eat, sleep, or exercise. You can fulfill all of these. You can choose to keep your prisoners happy or♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off. If they get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off, then they may try to smuggle spoons or forks out from the cafeteria. They may start fights when in the yard or when taking a shower. Some may try to escape, attacking your staff. You'll have to call a riot police if things get out of hand.When building your prison you are given several materials to build with. You can make concrete and brick buildings. There are a variety of different floors you can build with. You have different objects like Staff Door, Large Prison Door, Prison Door, TV, Bed, Table, Chair, and even more (There's a plus button on the menu to show more items). You have to hire your own staff. You start out with the Warden, Chefs, Guards, and Builders. To unlock more staff, your warden must research other people, who then may research other people. An example would be the warden researching the foreman. Then the foreman would research the janitor. Now you can clean up your grimy floors. Electricity and water don't come from no where, you must connect the power consuming objects to power supplying utilities. You start out with one power generator and one capacitor, which increases the amount of power you can supply to your prison. You use electric cable underground to connect different parts of your prison together. Water supplies are also fulfilled by a water pump, large pipes, and small pipes. There is also a planning function, which will allow you to sketch on your prison and get an idea on how your prison will look. This is a very important feature if you want to make sure your prison works good.Something you should nowWhile this game is very fun, it is still in Alpha! There are quite a few glitches and bugs that may make your game unplayable. The things for me have been builders not wanting to build things, the game saying there is no route to the object they are in fact able to get to, and prisoners getting stuck in solitary. I do have a working save, however, and it is very fun.Should You Buy It?I highly recommend this game, as it has so much to offer! And with it being in Alpha, there are many new features to come! Look past the bad side of the game, and enjoy it!Now I'll stop talking and you go play this game!

Posted: September 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Build a prison or even a mental hospital or Gulag (mods :) )Enforce a totalitarian merciless regime and suppress every prisoner into a mindless order following zombie orhave a "hippy" all needs covered, tv's in cells, pool tables for fun "prisons".. (u know like ones in Norway where you would ask to be checked in..All those work, you can choose how you want to run your prison, game gives you nice freedom of direction you are gonna run your facility..Lots of rooms, objects, staff.. connecting doors, cameras, remote control (like redstone in Minecraft ;) ) Even tho it's alpha, there's a lot to do in game, prison labor, education programs, high,med,low risk prisoner blocks, staff management, patrols and just looking at your "ant" colony function is quite interesting and satisfying..And who can leave riots out?? :D Contraband and misbehavior keep you and your staff on your toes.I sometimes save the game, then try to encourage a riot just to see how it will unfold, test your security, watch mayhem, fires, panic and destruction! if it's too devastating, just load to last save ;)Those were all pros, only cons for now would be performance issues (not optimized well, my macbook pro retina get really hot even tho it has very high specs..) didn't try playing on windows yet..of course there are bugs and some facilities, objects, staff etc don't work yet, but they will soon.Regular updates and change notes videos for every one show that devs care and are working hard to make this awesome game into a fully functioning 1.0 one day..Bottom line, if you love building, management, simulation games and prison stuff; and have patience to go through alpha, beta stages, then you will love this game and you should buy it! Development is going the right direction.I will add that it has a lot of tiny cool stuff hidden in the game and you realise it's actually much more fun than just a prison building game.. it has it's own character.I bought it as a part of a bundle, but would love to name one of the prisoners myself! :D (you can buy this as a dlc, but it's not cheap :/ )

Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Don't confuse this with the abysmal "Prison Tycoon" series. This game is still alpha, but it's getting updates monthly and already is highly playable. You build and manage a prison. How you do it is up to you, from left-wing utopia to right-wing hell hole. I'm usually aiming for the latter while somehow drifting towards the former. Oh well, that's what happens to me in most games with moral choices.The graphics are fine and do their jobs. The biggest downside are controls and the cluttered interface. Building cell blocks is unnecessarily tedious. Since the game gets improved with every patch, it is safe to assume that that we haven't see it nearly at its best yet.Highly recommended for everyone who likes tycoon games and The Sims.8,5/10

Posted: October 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Prison architect is your regular build and sruvive game with very intersting setting aka building perfect prison and keeping inmates safe and calm. Game is of course in early access so it will definetely change and evolve so keep that in mind.Tutorial - I really like the idea to make it something more like intro and letting player get immersed with whole prison setting, But for now I feel like creators had interesting idea but let it go and it feels lackluster. The tutorial part is too shallow and confusing and the story is too short. This can be much more interesting, especially with follow up in form of story driven missions/scenarios.Gameplay - considering this is work in progress I'm very satisfied in the way how the game works. So there is a nice UI with prison planning, clone tool. The AI works fine and gets job done for majority of time, be it prison personel or inmates themselves. Graphiscs are basic, quite clearly protrating everything with some artistic feeling.There is one major issue I have - you can build too nice prison without any challenge by chaining various projects that doesn't require any prisoners. I feel that game should have slower buildup with lower funds at the beginning so you have to put some compromises, instead having it all. My 2nd prison got to 100 capacity with absolutely no problems - no riots, escapes and no difficulty. Too easy too fast.I like the idea to make some inmates unique with various hidden perks and having nice background story and even graphics. Yet I think it's prisoners "psychology" that should be the major feature. As much as it's fun to have big prison full of inmates operating flawlessly I'd love to have more micromanagment of various prisoners(and guards), that react differently to cookie-cutter treatment. This will not only make game much more challenging but also each playtrough will be more unique with most favorite and hated personalities.The game is currently in great spot, easily worth the purchse already and it's really interesting to see and experience how it developes.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												I was recommended to try this game by friend. And rightfully so. There's so much to do, so many ways to build (or fubar) a prison. By turning on all variables sense of chaos and impending doom is always constant when prisoners are about to kill eachother, stuff, rioting or something else disastrous... Fires break out and random stuff keeps on happening always challenging and forcing to make decisions... When each prison build is different, inmates are random and random things occur every now and then it's very unique game experience each time. You just wondering when you will do too much mistakes and end up being prisoner yourself, trying to break out from the very prison you build...Only small downside is that rarely pathfinding gets confused and in few occasions it's been nigh impossible to clear/fix certain areas when game claims it's "too dangerous" to fix it - but doesn't give a hint WHY it is too dangerous to do so... Luckily those things happen really rarely and are bypassable with little thinking and tinkering.This is addictive, big, fun and very satisfying game to play, definitely recommended!

Posted: October 7, 2015
												So is Prison Architect fun to play? Well I believe it is once you have got in to even though the game is not with out it's flaws a rough gem if you will, some will love it and carve it out to be the shiny gem it is meant to be others will scoff at it and throw it back for ever being the dirty dingy gem is long to escape. The game has a lot of potential and is quite deep in the building of your prison even with it's simplified graphics that add a nice charm to it that will excited some and put others off. We even get to play as an inmate trying to escape getting in to fights etc, if we want from our very own prisons or even any ones prison who has been uploaded to the workshop if you want to.Pros --Graphics have a nice charm being simple-Building and running your own prison -Being able to try and escape your own prison-Story is quite good in game-Seems to have a lot of depth the more you play it-police Dogs-can get very bloody stopping riots or even causing them if your the one fighting-quite an easy interface to use when building etc once you got use to it-A lot of information give about your prison and inmates etcCons --Graphics very simple-comes across a bit more complicated then it should (But thanks to being able to pause and speed up as well as 5 campaigns/tutorial works well)-only 5 campaigns would like more since they seem a good quality  -Can get a bit boring waiting for some things to build (but has speed up time is in as as mentioned above so is not as big of negative as it could be)-Big prisons lag a little not much but a littleSo all in all a good game that is right for some but not others.Well here is a link to a video I did reviewing this game if you want more information below -

I called in riot police, paramedics and gave my armed guards permission to open fire.  Many died that day. The storm has now passed and I have created a super-max building dedicated to the most insane who enter my prison and everything is running smoothely.10/10 would shakedown again.

Posted: November 19, 2016
												Very fun game. You have all the tools to find illegal items, to punish prisoners or to make them somewhat happy with all reabilitation programs. Nice and simple graphics, easy to install mods. Doesn't judge you if you haven't fully completed tutorial and went straight to sandbox, because it says to you whats wrong in prison and it's (most of the time) easy to find how to fix it and it gives you time to do so. It's not kind of those real time strategies when game says something is wrong and it's already too late to fix it, unless you're expert on it. Also, while playing I saw a lot of fun things happen, for example prisoner sleeping handcuffed near his pickaxe and he was smilling :DSo yeah, but there are also some flaws, for example on some places game feels unfinished, for example it's too little of explanations on buildings and things you can build, but there is a mod which brings all information from official wiki to the game and it doesn't feel like something is off. Also I spent like a few hours when I finally find out why my prisoners can't make beds, this wasn't written any in game, but I found it on official wiki (before installing mod). So you may stumble upon some things which feels not finished or smth, but overall this game is awesome simple indie realtime strategy.One more thing, it's to expensive for it's price, so get it on sale. It's nothing new after like 10 hours of gameplay, so only thing that will make you play will be that you'll want to sell your prison and build another, bigger, greater, safer etc.

Posted: July 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								At this current time this game is in a early access state as it has been for some time now. I have played around 50 hours on this game so far and can safely say that i will be playing many, many hours on this game. It is highly addictive and is great to be able to make your own prison where you get to map it out, hire your staff, choose in sandbox whether to have low, medium or high risk prisoners. The higher the risk the more money they bring into your prison. You have to be on the ball and plan your prison out quickly as prisoners can quickly riot, smuggle weapons/tools/luxuries and attempt to escape. I had one enjoying but challanging instance where i had 100 high risk prisoners rioting at once, killing all my guards before doing a big break out. At that point i needed to sell my prison to start again. A thing about this game is that in time you will learn from a lot of mistakes but it has great potential and requires minimal graphical requirements to play this game, which i think is great! Awesome game, highly recommend it as it is very addictive. xD

Posted: February 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								The tutorial sucks, but don't do what I did and give up on the game for awhile because of that issue. The game doesn't take too long to figure out and is worth it as a charming and addictive building game. It has few bugs for early access, though it needs polish (including simple things like grammar). The one thing I've noticed so far as a problem is that your own success tends to lead to a less interesting game. I suppose this may be true of other 'build' games as well, but I've noticed it more with this one. Hopefully there will be more challenges added in, but either way it's a neat little concept that is well-executed.

Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Absolutely love this game. One of the best games Ive ever played. I put this right up there alongside Red Alert, Rise of Nations, Half Life and Team Fortress 2. The complexity of the game gives you plenty to do, and with mods added theres a ton of things to do. And whatsmore? There are no limits to what you can build or how big to build the prison. Just for kicks I tried seeing what the limits are: there are none; you can build practically infinite amounts of objects, utilities or staff. You can go as big as the sky if you want. With the Alpha's coming to a close in December, and the game to be released in full, I was hoping for a few extra features in the game itself to allow for mods like, trucks taking a different route into the prison, or multi-floors. Im sure someone will figure out how to manipulate the game code to do that. But for now, I give this game two thumbs way up for its creativity and fun.

								Prison Architect scratches that itch that was left behind by roller coaster tycoon.  It's wonderfully simple. You build a prison. How you manage that prison is entirly up to you. Want to build the prison out of hell, you can. Someone smuggled in a cellphone, Guess he's not seeing the ligt of day anytime soon >:D. Or you can be more forgiving. Both ways offer different chalenges. Be advised it's still only alpha build right now but with the recent update there has been a lot of improvements performance wise. However it's rather stable. Also, DOG AI (apparantly that's a selling point for AAA games these days).I recommend this game, it's not everyone's cup of tea but it sure can be entertainig.

Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Promising and already very fun in the current state.Typical tycoon game, for those enjoying the genre it's a must have.Pros:+ A lot of options and choices+ Freedom of playing how you want+ Immersive+ Good balance / difficulty+ Modding (this doesn't interest me but it's there)Cons (advices for the dev):- Badly lacks hotkeys, too much clicking- No storyline or built-in objectives- Could get use of ever more choices, some are not finished (electric chair)- Some bugs around (sometimes items stacks and block each other’s from being removed ; can't remove tunnels at the extreme border of the map)- Had some lags in certain situations (might be linked to above bug)- Staff and Inmates management a bit lacking. Menu not very effective in that regard, clicking doesn't select the profile of the person, etc.- Buy menu (items, walls, ...) needs inside categories (ex. by room for items - in/out door for walls, etc.).- Need more control over workshops and other activities, as well as worker path, and stuff like that.- Positioning of items a bit strange (pre-build highlight unclear regarding to orientation), visuals bugs (doors opening on other stuff)Tbh I could go on and on with stuff "to improve" but it's entirely because I love the game and it shows potential and opens all of those great ideas and asks for more.

Posted: April 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Prison Architect is just a fantastic game. At the beginning taking out grants and building a basic detention centre can be very easy, but you have to make sure that you think of all the factors that could affect your prisoners. One wrong move and you may go in the red.You have to gradually expand your prison, instead of allowing tons of prisoners at once. For example, if you have maximum security prisoners, you cannot accept them all at once in the beginning, because of how the prisoners will react to the little you have in the prison at the beginning, and you have to make sure that you accept prisoners at the right time, or they will just riot.The variety of the rooms and programs the game has is just phenomenal in this alpha stage, all the extra activities and programs the prisoners can do and you can expand on really makes the game never get boring.I highly recommend this game, especially in this stage of development where you can see all the new rooms and interactions being added into the game, because I think that many more things are to be added into the game.

Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a very solid simulation/tycoon game, however it does suffer from a few setbacks. There isn't much in the way of a tutorial, so it might take a few trys before you find your stride. My first prison ran more like a concentration camp, but by the third I had the game figured out. That being said, there wasn't much motivation to create a fourth. Once you've established a prison that can run essentially without any input from you, there is the option to sell the prison and begin anew with the profits. Do this once or twice, of course, and you've really done everything the game has to offer. Still, the same argument might be had for a large majority of the tycoon games out there, so it's not enough of a drawback for me to not recommend the game. Four Stars.

								This is a good game. GOOD not great. I first got the game and played it for about 1 week practically non-stop, then realised the annoying things about it, Awful texture bugs like refridgerators that sit out in the middle of the floor when you want them on the wall, stupid patrol times, when you set a patrol route half the time the officer on it is taking a break so to get an officer on it at all times you need like 4 officers on the same route, and not to mention the lazyness of the construction workers. Posted: September 6, 2016
												There's tons going on in this game. You can play it for hours, days, years. But you are always starting over from square 1. There are no other squares. There is no variety- only male, female, normal, cheating, and increasing difficulty levels. The tutorial is long and story heavy, unlike the rest of the game, which is pure sim/building/management. And you can't really fiddlefaddle your way to victory. A lot of careful decisions need to be made.

Posted: November 19, 2016
												Very fun game. You have all the tools to find illegal items, to punish prisoners or to make them somewhat happy with all reabilitation programs. Nice and simple graphics, easy to install mods. Doesn't judge you if you haven't fully completed tutorial and went straight to sandbox, because it says to you whats wrong in prison and it's (most of the time) easy to find how to fix it and it gives you time to do so. It's not kind of those real time strategies when game says something is wrong and it's already too late to fix it, unless you're expert on it. Also, while playing I saw a lot of fun things happen, for example prisoner sleeping handcuffed near his pickaxe and he was smilling :DSo yeah, but there are also some flaws, for example on some places game feels unfinished, for example it's too little of explanations on buildings and things you can build, but there is a mod which brings all information from official wiki to the game and it doesn't feel like something is off. Also I spent like a few hours when I finally find out why my prisoners can't make beds, this wasn't written any in game, but I found it on official wiki (before installing mod). So you may stumble upon some things which feels not finished or smth, but overall this game is awesome simple indie realtime strategy.One more thing, it's to expensive for it's price, so get it on sale. It's nothing new after like 10 hours of gameplay, so only thing that will make you play will be that you'll want to sell your prison and build another, bigger, greater, safer etc.

Posted: September 3, 2016
												Prison Architect offers an incredibley in depth game. Not only do you need to build a secure, Well thought out prison you have to take in to account of and plan for the tiny details from guard patrol routes to drug rehabilitation programs.Run the prison with an iron fist and expect riots.No kitchen and expect your prisoners to slowly starve to death.Educate the prisoners and help them become fully functioning members of society less likely to re-offend. Build all the key elements of a prison, cells, solitary, visiting rooms, kitchens, workshops, classrooms and much more.Sim-type games are always overlooked,Within the first few minutes of playing, The cartoon-like prisoners and environments set you up for what you think will be a fairly lighthearted game but the first few tutorial levels soon contrast this and turn fairly dark (you need to build an execution chamber).There are cut scenes of a fashion covering with plenty of swearing in the dialog (hence the age 16 rating).The soundtrack is also well suited with atmospheric music kicking in at all the right times in the missions.By this point you already know if this game is of interest to you.It's a rare simulation game.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Not since Tropico, and Dungeon Keeper, has pain and suffering been so much fun. Watch in horror as your ideas for a safe, clean, well-equiped facility are replaced by a terrifying fortress of squallor and oppression as you struggle to keep your budget in the black. Give into temptation, and quell that disgruntled mob by hiring armed guards who crush complaints under the jackboots of tranquility. Laugh the first time you give the "weapons free" order during an uprising and watch as your guards simultaneously solve the rioting and crowding problems. And then feel bad because you are a monster. Also be prepared for a never ending stream of spoon murders throughout your prison.After 4 years this Early Access gem has finally hit the big time. The only bad thing, is that by departing Early Access, the average quality level of EA has dropped.

Posted: January 12, 2016
												I was recommended to try this game by friend. And rightfully so. There's so much to do, so many ways to build (or fubar) a prison. By turning on all variables sense of chaos and impending doom is always constant when prisoners are about to kill eachother, stuff, rioting or something else disastrous... Fires break out and random stuff keeps on happening always challenging and forcing to make decisions... When each prison build is different, inmates are random and random things occur every now and then it's very unique game experience each time. You just wondering when you will do too much mistakes and end up being prisoner yourself, trying to break out from the very prison you build...Only small downside is that rarely pathfinding gets confused and in few occasions it's been nigh impossible to clear/fix certain areas when game claims it's "too dangerous" to fix it - but doesn't give a hint WHY it is too dangerous to do so... Luckily those things happen really rarely and are bypassable with little thinking and tinkering.This is addictive, big, fun and very satisfying game to play, definitely recommended!

Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Best Early Access game I have ever played. The game gets updates each month, and the updates are always major new game elements, not just little bug fixes. The goal of the game is to make a prison as large as possible that easily, safely and efficiently maintains your prisoners with as little rioting and death as possible, this is not an easy task.There is no way to win, but you are able to sell your prison to make your next one larger, more creative and more fun.The modding community is excelent and if you ever get bored with the game you can find a mod that will spice things up until the next update which is usually less than a month away.This game has been constantly updated for 31 months, introversion rocks, you wont get ripped off with this early access game!The lies about the bugs in the other negative reviews are false.... every month the few bugs that exist are patched, and in my time since alpha 13, I have yet to encounter so called "game breaking bugs"

Posted: November 28, 2016
												Definitely one of my favourite games. If you are like me and love strategy games, resource management games, tycoon games, and upgrade games, then this is the game for you. The replay value in this game is insane. I have built dozens of prisons for prisoners with different levels of security and with different goals for my prison in mind but (in my opinion) the best part of Prison Architect is managing your prison. Monitoring the prisoner's needs to prevent riots, assigning prisoners like snitches and ex-cops to protective custody, sweeping for controband, adding security precautions where needed, and hiring guards and staff are all things you can do in Prison Architect. Also, for an added layer of difficulty, there is not an option to have gangs in your prison.

Posted: June 11, 2016
												I absolutely love Prison Architect! When I first saw it on 'early access' I didn't think I'd like it. But when it was on sale I decided to give it a shot, and I'm absolutely glad that I did. Yes, there are some performance issues, especially FPS when you have more than 1,000 prisoners, but Introversion has been working on the performance and making improvements.There's also a bit of a learning curve in the beginning, but you can watch videos on YouTube to help you with your initial design - from there you can use your imagination and learn from your mistakes.Catch PA on sale and buy it if you enjoy sim games - you won't be disappointed once you learn the basics! Also, the player made mods are fantastic and add a new level of enjoyment.

Posted: June 15, 2016
												Really good management game. You manage all aspects of a prison, from the rooms layout, electrical grid, and water distribution, to prisoners schedules, guards deployment, punishment policy, etc. You can choose to punish a lot your prisoners or make them feel at home with nice cells and reform programs to help them go back in society, it's all your choice.Furthermore, the game offers a lot of technical items you can play with to fully automatize your prison, enhance security, etc.With all that, it's still noob friendly, and you won't have to play long to get the basics.Pros :-Quite deep prison management : You control everything, from buildings layout and electrical grid to prisoners schedules, guards deploymlent, etc.-Can be extended further with mods.-Only decent prison management game I know.-Short, yet nice campaign that teach you the basics really well.-Prisons can be shared easily through steam.-Devs are still updating the game, and currently working on a more polished 2.0 update.Cons :-Can't really think of anything, maybe some little bugs.

Posted: June 20, 2016
One of the Best Prison SimulatorsThis is an addictive simulator in which you are tasked to manage a prison. There is a decent tutorial at the start which brings you up to speed on the basics of running the prison, as well as having a story with it which was a nice touch. If you are a player that enjoys micromanagement, then this game is definitely one that you'll enjoy, as you have control over almost every aspect of the prison. However, this can also be a deterrent for those that can't quite be bothered because if you don't keep some particular things in check, it will lead to problems in your prison which you'll end up having to solve and deal with the consequences. The graphics are simplistic but suits the style, as is allows for easy tracking of what's going on, and the sounds are nice to. There are many online guides to this game which is good because after the tutorial, the game doesn't hold you hand. In addition to this, they have integrated steam workshop which has allowed for many mods and prebuilt prisons to be experimented with. The developers have been great since early access, constantly pushing updates for the game that fixes issues for the game and adds new features. If you're looking to get sucked away for many hours into a simulator, then i'd definitely recommend this one.

Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game, still in Alpha, has plenty of bugs to go around. That said, I didn't find any to be game breaking, and most of them fixed themselves after some experimentation on my part. It's all part of early access!Now the game itself. Part builder, part management game. A Sim City of prisons, and I mean the old style sim cities. It has charm, humor, strategy, and pure excellence. Herein find my pros and cons!PROS-Cute minimal graphics-Lots of room and material options-Stories on all inmates-Good strategy inside-It's as difficult as you make it to beCONS-Bugs (a given)-Lack of polishBare in mind that the only cons are basically due to the fact that it's in Alpha stage, which we know going in. IN CLOSINGThis game is one of the reasons early access can be fantastic.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												Prison Architect is basically Sim City. But, instead of a city you manage your prison.Your job is to make sure, that no one escapes your prison.  An important part of that is keeping your prisoners happy and fullfilling their needs. That means you have to make sure everyone has enough to eat, can be visited and read etc. For me this game has a nice balance between complexity and the freedom to build the prison you want.Sadly the GUI is very complex and split up and the new added Escape Mode is not very fun, at least for me. Mostly you grind reputation through starting riots until you and your team are strong enough to get out.But after all, the normal gameplay mode is very fun and provides hours of tinkering with your prison.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												Awesome little game and the shining light for any aspiring EA developer.  The game does exactly what you expect, you can build a prison and then manage it.The campaign functions well as a good tutorial to the game.  I wish there were more grant objectives in the main game, but there are enough to keep you interested for a long time.There are a few bugs that crop up every now and again, but I've found that they usually right themselves if you save and reload the map.  This happens to me maybe once every 30-40 hrs and only on my largest prisons. Also, if you want multiples of some buildings in your prison, the AI can do some stupid things (like have 20 cooks at one kitchen, instead of 10 working in each of the two kitchens.  I would like the ability to assign staff to certain work areas (the same way you can assign prisoners to certain work areas).  But these really are minor gripes.If you like management sims or even city builders, you will probably get a lot of enjoyable gaming hours from Prison Architect.8/10.

Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Solid entertainment and great value for money. Very addictive. This game will steal many, many hours from you.However.. despite all the great things that can and have been said about this game, remember it is an alpha. There are bugs. Lots of them (more than 3000, according to the latest alpha release video). I haven't experienced crashes or corrupted save games or anything like that, but sooner or later you will run into bugs that are really annoying. Like the fact that garbage dropped in a jail door tile will keep the door open at all times, and because the game doesn't recognize drops in a door tile, the garbage will never be picked up by a janitor. Imagine what a permanently open jail door can do for a prison. So yeah.. stuff like that..The UI isn't great, and it's obvious that the more new features the developers add, the more cramped and unintuitive the UI gets. It really needs an overhaul to be efficient. But it's an alpha, so maybe it will get one at some point.There's little to no guidance for new players to introduce them to the game mechanics. All it offers is a useless tutorial where you build an electric chair, that isn't really used for anything in the actual game. If you want to know what the various buildings does (what purpose they have) you have to look it up on the wiki. For end game players there's a distinct lack of feeling of progress. The tech tree is pretty small, it doesn't take long to max everything out.But, having said all that: buy this game. It's great.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Love this game.  It's a well designed and well executed foray into designing and running your own prison. The mechanics are deeper than one might guess at first glance, and there's lots of tools at your disposal with which to either build your dream reform-based prison, or your dream complex of human-rights violations (or somewhere in the middle). I only played for the tail end of Alpha (the last 6-8 months or so); but I can safely say Introversion has been active and engaged with this game, even after making the final push from Early Access to full release. Their monthly Alpha development videos can still be seen on Youtube (along with their funny, self-depricating early alpha trailer that was initially what attracted me to the game).Now delightfully bug-free (or bug-minimal), the full release includes a campaign in addition to the core sandbox-style prison builder we've come to know and love.  The campaign serves as a tutorial to the game's mechanics, as well as giving an overall frame to the "world" of prison architect.   While much of the campagin's gameplay is a bit same-y for people who have been extensively building their own prisons, the story itself is compelling and keeps you treking towards the next snippet of story. Having said that, one chapter included gameplay I hadn't actually experienced due to my play style, which was a nice change of pace. For newcomers it is an excellent addition to give some scope of what the game can do.No game AI is without its issues, but the rate at which I find myself cursing my prison staff or wishing something had been designed differently is pretty minimal. The vast majority of issues my prisons have experienced have had something to do with something I've personally overlooked, which is exactly the experience you want to be having. TL;DR -- Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes contruction/management sims. An excellent experience. Well designed. Engaged development team.

								-Thought prison was going well-Had three seperate cell blocks, one for each level of security prisoner.-All is well in the save file of 'SUPER PRISON OF HAPPY DEATH'-Suddenly new arrival John 'Magic' Mumbo-Legendary Prisoner-Ten minutes pass, riot in max security shower room -Mumbo disarms guard, takes shotgun and goes on rampage while 20 other prisoners take the scraps from Mumbo's terror spree-Finally subdue Mumbo with 2 guard dogs and 3 taser guards-Shakedown search of entire prison 10 minutes later-Find 16 jail keys, 26 tasers, and 28 shotguns in prisoners cells/inventory11/10 Would get destroyed by Magic Mumbo and have shotguns become currency again.

Posted: July 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Prison Architect is the first game that got me into buying Alpha/Beta games.  What a joy it has been to progress with this game and its updates.  This game pretty much has it all.  You get the simulation by building your own prison.  This can be done very easily or (if you intend to have alots of prisoners who are hard criminals) this can be very hard.  The game includes fincial managment, but not to a level of frustration.  You start off in a small prison where one of the prisoners is being put to death.  Your first job is to make a death row cell for them.  You easily learn the basics of the game as you start to build.  Once this is done, you're left on your own to build, create, destory, and exapnd.It is up to you if you want to reform your prisoners and give them jobs, education and other skills.  Or as Warden you can keep them locked up tightly unable to have any freedoms.  Gangs fight often and snitches get stiches real quick!  Find a few CIs to help you keep the hard to handle prisoners under control.Train your guards, hire some guard dogs, and build a nice security system.  Your limits are boundless, truely.  And don't let the Alpha scare you away.  The game bugs are fixed quickly and any updates make you seem like you've gotten a brand new game.Enjoy!

Posted: December 15, 2016
												If you want to lose sleep, this game will do it - not because it's scary, but because it's so incredibly addictive, you'll lose track of time and become a mindless zombie, glued to the keyboard. There are different ways to play - you can run a men's or women's prison but no co-ed. The women's prison comes equipped with nurseries and sad little inmates carrying babies around. It's a little stressfull, worrying about babies in cages with murderers, but what can you do? You can choose to be a cruel and harsh warden, or the coolest warden ever. You can make a prison where people are dying to get in, or dying before they get out. The possibilites are great and the game is well worth the money.
